top_comment.text:
In all honesty while I absolutely love this game, the backwards logic here 
is that Nintendo's top priority concerning fun is design and solid game 
play.  In order to provide a full, 100% potentially fun experience, they 
need to take a step outside their little security box/bubble and learn to 
*extend* that potential to *include* presentation (graphics and audio)  and 
balance each aspect equally.  Now don't get me wrong, here, coming from 
somebody who games on 1 each from the big 3, handhelds included; Super 
Mario 3D World already looks really good and well put together on its own, 
but I mean they could be doing so much more to modernize and the looks and 
feel of every character, every universe in their franchises to achieve and 
inspire more believability if they just added more necessary layers of 
texture to really make their games pop and feel alive and somewhat real, or 
at least believable.  For instance, straight from the Super Smash Bros 
Brawl trailer (or possibly the more current 1, I don't quite recall if he 
retained the same texurized appearance), you could see how Mario's overalls 
looks closer to real clothes, his shirt and cap even, maybe his hair and 
mustache?  Why can't he look like this in his own platformer despite the 
trailer?  Why can't the Mushroom Kingdom present more liveliness like that 
for matter?  What about Pokemon; With the ever growing amount you can't 
possibly tell me you haven't even remotely dreamed or imagined a more 
realistic looking version of your favorite 1 in our world.  How about 
Metroid, which probably already does a fair job in its own respect, maybe 
Kid Icarus? (Uprising being the best resourceful reference here, which I 
image also provides its fair share)  Hell, even Donkey Kong *shudder* 
(Sorry, just never been a fan of this 1) could benefit from these factors; 
I've not once seen the guy take a step outside the side-scrolling genre of 
his own series and into the 3D world model for a change.  What's up with 
that, Nintendo?  Long story short, if Nintendo expects to gain back its 
once loyal fanbase from our retro veteran days, they just need to step up 
and expand all of that untapped potential in order to play with the big 
boys. otherwise the majority will continue to see them as 2nd best despite 
their reputation which i'm honestly not knocking.  What the don' realize is 
that if they don't take any risks (like on solid, reliable hardware for 
example) they're only holding themselves back, plus how to learn from their 
mistakes and that i's OK.  Nobody will ever think any less of them if 
they'd at least try a little harder.  These aren't the easy go lucky 1-up 
days of Nintendo vs Sega, anymore, they have some serious competition on 
their hands now. slightly beyond Micro$oft and $ony for that matter, just 
not so much on the same scale.﻿
top_comment.author: DaveGX

comments.text:
+xXNinjaRunnerXx Yeah, I don't really know much any more way to explain it 
than just adding more layers of texture and detail to create or immerse 
more believable worlds in the sense of imagining them.  1 thing I'll say 
while they may not pertain to Nintendo games or even game graphics in 
general, is whenever I've seen the earlier live action Halo trailers, even 
some of the current 1s here and there, despite everything else I learn of 
the game play, is rather what really gets me jacked for a game and become 
more immersed because it's just so alive and while it's completely fiction, 
it looks like a believable reality.  But that's just me because I'm all for 
sci-fi, not so much for WW/civil/modern combat because history wasn't 
really a strong suit for me so I never really connected with it.  That 
said, half the time I'm not completely in it for the competitive side much 
anymore, but because every once in a while if I get a chance to see parts 
of their universe so amazing I'll take it whenever I can.  That's pretty 
much more or less why I'd like to see Nintendo take their IPs up a notch 
and I'm not saying they have to go nitty gritty or Mortal Kombat on them; 
It's just that more or less they've always been the 1s with the best 
franchises, (Sega for Sonic the Hedgehog anyway) that always kept me 
playing an focused  for hours and hours, day after day, that kept us on our 
feet to this very day.  So it'd just kinda be nice to take a little more of 
that with us without feeling like we've outgrown them.  I don't know, I 
guess the best way I can think of it is that perhaps the games we all knew 
and loved so much from back in the day should grow with us a little, that's 
all.
comments.author: DaveGX

comments.author: TheLWebb100

comments.text:
+Shahe Ansar False, it is you who can't accept reality. Here's an article 
that I've copy and pasted so that you may better understand why the Wii U 
sucks.

*1. The Weird Controller Stew*
You can’t get much less simple than the Wii U’s controller setup. There's 
the gamepad and the Wii remote, with some games requiring both, especially 
in multiplayer. There's the Pro Controller. There's the coming 
GameCube-inspired controller. In multiplayer, only one player can have the 
gamepad, which can lead to fights over it or general confusion as it is 
exchanged from hand to hand. The Wii sold itself through simplicity, the 
Wii U is weirdly complex. One of the most common questions among those new 
to the console is simply, "what controllers do I need?" 

*2. The Gamepad Perplexes Even Nintendo*
When you introduce a new, innovative technology, it's a good idea to have 
some idea of what to do with it, but it soon become apparent that Nintendo 
had few ideas for the gamepad. They used it in a few party games, but 
increasingly ignored it for everything but off-TV play. Only after a couple 
of disastrous years and suggestions that the Wii U should simply be 
re-released without the pricey controller has Nintendo started working on 
doing something with the thing.

*3. Third Party Support is Virtually Nonexistent*
There’s a big different between getting third party publishers to announce 
a handful of games for a console before launch and getting real support for 
it. After failing with a few ports of aging games, then noticing the Wii 
U's weak sales, most publishers have lost all interest in the console.

Third party publishers would love to have successful games on a Nintendo 
system, but for the most part non-Nintendo games just don’t do well, and if 
there's anything that Nintendo could do to change that, they certainly 
haven't done it.

*4. It's Underpowered*
Why did people buy the Xbox 360 and the PS3? Better graphics. That was the 
selling point; these systems would blow you away with a level of detail 
you’ve never seen before. What is the Wii U offering? Graphics that may be 
slightly better than those of the 360 and PS3, and inferior to those of the 
XB1 and PS4. Why on earth would anyone buy the Wii U over a comparable 
machine with a backlog of high-def games or new, far more powerful systems? 
Especially since that lack of power means many new games are not, according 
to their developers, possible on the Wii U?

*5. The Controller is Less Impressive Than an iPhone*
If you’re going to do something, do it right. Sure, the Wii gamepad's touch 
screen is a clever idea, but it also feels like it’s already behind the 
technological curve. While an iPhone is multi-touch, allowing you to do 
things like expand a photo by pulling it like taffy, the Wii U’s controller 
is single touch, like their DS. And while the inner-facing camera might 
allow games to do cute things like put you on screen, an outer-facing 
camera that could let the controller perfectly align itself with the TV 
would seem far more useful.

*6. It's Too Expensive for What It Is*
Sure, it's cheaper than the PS4 and XB1, but the Wii U's price compares 
poorly with the last-gen consoles that equal it in power; right now you can 
get a 4 GB Xbox 360 with Kinect for $250 or a 500GB PS3 for just a little 
more. The Wii U is $300, with only 32GB of storage. This would be fine if 
the Wii U were a technological advance over the others, but for a console 
that's no more powerful than its aging competition, the price still seems 
high. 

True, it's cheaper than a PS4 or XB1, but it also only has a fraction of 
the power.

*7. No Internal Hard Drive*
Storage space is yet another of Nintendo’s many blind spots. When they 
created the Wii they didn’t even consider the issues of downloading games, 
and even balked when gamers demanded a solution. This time around, they are 
still relying on flash memory, although at least internal memory has gone 
to a choice of 8 or 32 GB from the half GB in the Wii. You can, at least, 
attach a USB drive, although about the last thing in my life I need is yet 
another device I have to plug into my power strip.

*8. Dodgy Online*
Nintendo has never understood online gaming. Market forces have dragged 
them, kicking and screaming, towards very minimal online capabilities, but 
they have never really seemed to believe that online gaming was necessary 
or desirable, nor have they focused resources on it the way they needed to. 
The Wii U's online is certainly an improvement for Nintendo, but they're 
years behind the competition.

*9. Deserts Its Casual Base*
The Wii was a brilliant idea; a controller so easy and intuitive that it 
drew a slew of non-gamers into the world of videogames. Now, after having 
sold consoles to millions of non-gamers, Nintendo seems to be done with 
their converts, and is putting out a controller with the very collection of 
triggers and buttons that kept casual gamers from playing videogames 
pre-Wii. Sure, the Wii U still has the Wii’s remote and nunchuk, but those 
are increasingly ignored, meaning there’s no reason for casual gamers to 
even consider upgrading to the new system. This leaves Nintendo in a fight 
with Sony and Microsoft for the very core gamers who consider the Wii U 
beneath notice.

*10. Iffy Core Game Commitment*
Nintendo claimed that with the Wii U they were making something for the 
core gamers they had ignored throughout the Wii’s history. The Wii U, would 
not just be a console for tots and grandmas; this time around there would 
be far more games that could compete with the adult fare found on Sony and 
Microsoft consoles.

But there weren't. Sure, they saved Bayonetta 2 and made it a Wii U 
exclusive, and two years later they did the same for Devil's Third, but a 
single core title every couple of years is hardly worth mentioning. 
Nintendo likes to develop family-friendly games, and while some series, 
like Legend of Zelda, Pikmin and Metroid Prime, are loved by core gamers, 
Nintendo’s own output will always skew towards families. With no support 
from third parties, the Wii U remains the province of tots and grandmas.

*11. Gives Less Extras Than the Competition*
While Sony and Microsoft wanted to be both gaming machines and media 
centers, Nintendo still believes that a game console should just be a game 
console. It should not play DVDs, or BluRay, or be an MP3 player. Well, 
they’re wrong. Increasingly, gamers aren’t even buying those things, they 
just use the versions that come with their consoles. If someone wants a 
game console and a BluRay player, are they really going to buy one of each 
when they can just get a PS3 or PS4? As in so many cases, Nintendo is 
living in the past, and ignoring what we living in the present have come to 
expect from our machines; everything.

True, you can watch Netflix, and you've got TVii, which I suppose someone 
actually uses, but that pales in comparison with the competition.

*12. Nintendo Has Lost Its Mojo*
One of the main arguments for the success of the Wii U is simply that 
Nintendo has proven previous naysayers wrong with the Wii, which industry 
analysts predicted would be a flash-in-the-pan, and the DS, which many saw 
as a gimmick there was no real need for. But the poor sales of the 3DS that 
resulted in a shocking $80 price cut suggest that Nintendo’s winning streak 
could be coming to a close. While the 3DS did rebound, the falter with 
which it began, and with which the Wii U began, suggests that Nintendo may 
be getting shakier in their grasp of the market.
comments.author: The Ninja-X³

top_comment.text:
This game is great, however so many of us were expecting an open 3d mario 
game like 64 or sunshine. This game definitely gets the fun factor right 
(in milestones), but open world is still much better than linear. There's 
more sense of awe to the levels, and secrets are much harder to find/have 
more impact. It feels more like a "world" when it's open 3d rather than 
linear 3d.

This game is far from bad, it's still amazing. But I just think that it was 
timed poorly on the Wii U. If they had come out with the open world Mario 
game first, then this game would have been received MUCH better. We are all 
craving the open world Mario, as the last one we have seen was Sunshine. 
Galaxy and it's sequel were AMAZING, (I still consider them to be the best 
3d Mario Games), but they weren't truly open. It was fine back then because 
the last game was Sunshine, but here, we need the open world Mario game 
again.

This isn't a true 3d Mario game. This has become a series of it's own, 
which I'm cool with (really), but I am fearful that it's replacing the main 
series of open-world 3d Mario games that we haven't seen since sunshine, 
and an extent, Galaxy.﻿
top_comment.author: MG3DD

comments.text:
I loved the "linear" stages, made me feel i was playing a MARIO GAME.
But they are not that linear, they have secrets and cool stuff going 
around. Get all the green stars and say is linear after!
comments.author: Wenceslao Futanaki

comments.text:
+MG3DD I personally believe that Mario Games are best enjoyed when the 
gameplay is somewhat linear (of course you don't want it to be too linear 
or vice versa), but is arcade like in execution. I enjoy the open world 
like structures of the levels in Sunshine and 64 (Sunshine being my 
favorite Mario game for nostalgic reasons), but I think Mario games work 
better as tight, precision controlled platformers. The overall experience 
is condensed and isn't drawn out, in which I felt some levels where in both 
those games. The frantic fast pace nature of older mario games are really 
exhilarating and most importantly fun. Games like SMG2 and SM3DW do this 
superbly. Nintendo provides the Mario games a good contrast with the Zelda 
and Metroid games, so I think you should really delve into those games if 
you're looking for a fun nonlinear experience.
comments.author: Aaron Funes

comments.text:
I prefer Mario 3d Land/World for that exact same reason , i like more 
linear Mario than the 3d ones , boths are good but SM3d Land/World was live 
a love letter to me .
comments.author: Uliseh

comments.text:
actually right off the bat you can get the pete Parana shine before getting 
mission one of the first world. and there's also all the blue coins 
scattered around. This open design leads to the player having more freedom 
and thus challenges that can't arise in a linear game.
There both valid ways of making games I'm just slightly miffed that we have 
only been getting linear games now a days.
comments.author: Wolf Deity

comments.text:
+mariogalaxythree in Sunshine you could only get the Shinesprite of the 
given mission, you could get the 100 coin Shinesprite but you could only 
get them in missions that allowed you get 100 coins. 64 was the only game 
that allowed you collect power stars out of order and the mechanic hasn't 
been seen since. In my opinion I believe this allows for more streamlined 
level design and challenges that just can't get in open world platformers.
comments.author: Sean Maguire

comments.text:
but they were all very constrained compaired to what 64 and sunshine 
offered along with not letting you do stars out of order or while in a 
different mission.

comments.author: Sean Maguire

comments.text:
+Daniel Page
Yes, it's "3d", in the fact that the levels have 3 dimensions and 
characters. But true 3d is a nonlinear experience, in which there are 
always multiple paths, and secrets are often far-out. I want to play a 
Mario game in which you are rewarded for thinking on your own, not the way 
the game wants you to think. Even though the flagpole/star is easy to 
reach, it's always more rewarding when you explore every nook and cranny. 
You can argue that this game has that, but it is better when the secrets 
are more diverse and spread out, which is only possible if you have a truly 
open environment.
comments.author: MG3DD

comments.text:
+Daniel Page I kinda does because outside of optional challenges there is 
really only one route to the Star.

captions.text:
You’ve probably heard a lot about Nintendo
lately. About how they’re doomed. About

how the Wii U’s terrible, and it’s probably
gonna be their last console. You’ve probably

heard your money is better spent on a real
system, with real games. And power. You’ve

probably heard Nintendo is irrelevant. Well,
forget what you’ve heard. Forget the blogs,

forget the critics, forget all the bros who
are so quick to shrug off Nintendo. Because
they’ve forgotten something, too.

They’ve forgotten that fun will never be
irrelevant.

And fun is something these bros…still do
better than anyone.

There’s something intangible that sets this
game apart from just about everything else

I’ve played this year. Maybe even in years—it’s
really that good. Super Mario 3D World displays

a level of game design that’s, just…light
years ahead of virtually everyone else. And

then there’s the execution, which is even
more incredible. Every coin, every corner,

every Koopa…there’s not a single pixel
that doesn’t shine with polish, and care.

In fact, this is a game that makes other games,
even other good games…almost seem kind of
amateur.

Mario’s just playing in a different league
these days.

And it’s stunning that, after 30 years,
he’s somehow getting better.

And I think part of it is that…Nintendo
is totally rethinking the Super Mario series.

It used to be easy, right? You had the 2D
games, and you had the 3D games. They were

two different things, and they actually started
moving in two different directions. 3D World

pulls them back together. It takes 2D and
3D Mario, and reworks them into something
that’s…a little bit of both.

And it’s never as artificial as, just…mixing
some 3D levels with a few 2D levels. The point

is, those divisions don’t exist here. It’s
a new kind of Mario, built from all the old
kinds of Mario.

And it starts, surprising as it may be, with
Super Mario Bros. 2. You can play as one of

four characters. There’s Mario, Luigi, Toad
and Princess Peach, just like Mario 2. And

each of those characters has their own specific
attributes, just like Mario 2. For a moment,

Peach can hang in the air. Luigi can jump
higher than his brother, but Mario is more

sure-footed. And the thing is, they’re all
available right from the start. So you’re

free to play each level with whichever character
you want, as often you want…and each time,
it feels different.

There’s a freedom to that that seems obvious,
but it’s actually pretty brilliant. Why

limit fun, right? Why give the player arbitrary
restrictions? Super Mario 3D World never does
that.

Of course, once you’re in the levels…the
gameplay is just incredible. If ever there

was a guidebook on how a platformer should
play, this is it. Every time you touch the

analog stick, you move with a tightness and
fluidity that’s both precise and natural.

It just feels right. I mean, that’s what
the Mario games have always been about. The

joy of movement. Despite all the game’s
new ideas, that simple joy is still behind
everything that makes 3D World so wonderful.

The controls almost disappear. And Mario just
becomes an extension of yourself.

Provided you like to…dress like cats. I
mean, whatever you’re into.

Speaking of which, it wouldn’t be a Mario
game without power-ups. This time around,

the main attraction is the Cat Suit. There’s
a little mushroom shaped like a bell, and

it turns Mario into this spunky cat that can
climb walls, whack enemies with his paw…even

shoot forward like a feline missile. The Cat
Suit is this game’s Raccoon Leaf, or Bee

Suit…it’s the headliner. But the coolest
new power-up might actually be the Double
Cherry.

Each one sort of…clones Mario. You can have
up to five running around at once, and some

of the game’s most ingenious levels revolve
entirely around the Double Cherry.
And keeping all your Marios alive.

And you know, I mentioned Mario 2, but…one
of the things that’s immediately apparent

in this game…is that Nintendo is really
embracing their three decades of Mario masterpieces.

Because though they’re moving the series
forward, they’re also incorporating its

past. And it’s not just the playable characters.
Mario 2’s slot machines are also back, music
in tact.

Mario 3’s item houses are back, music in
tact.

Even Mario 64’s sliding levels are back.
Yes, with the music in tact.

And it’s clear that…one of the benefits
of forging this new mixture of 2D and 3D is

that it allows 3D World to embrace all the
series’ history. It becomes a celebration

of Mario’s past, while also pushing him
into a new era. And that combined with the

creative level designs and inventive gameplay
ideas…is why 3D World is such a brilliant
piece of design.

Of course, all the brilliant ideas in the
world wouldn’t matter if the execution wasn’t

there. It’s there, in this game. Mario’s
world looks absolutely stunning, and where

HD really benefits this cartoony look…is
in the details. The snow sparkles, grass blows

in the wind, things like clouds and even places
in the distance have this subtle haze. And

the weird thing is that, that polish actually
gives the game a sense of realism.

It’s a remarkable effect, and Mario’s
whimsical world has never looked better.

In fact, I’m not sure Mario’s ever played
better, either. This isn’t just the killer

app the Wii U was still lacking. This is a
stunning piece of game design, and a triumph

in game making. And I think it underscores
something that way too many of us forget.

In an industry where priorities have changed,
video games are still at their best…when
they’re fun.

Nintendo may do a lot of things poorly, but
fun isn’t one of them.
And once again, Mario proves it.

title: CGR Undertow - SUPER MARIO 3D WORLD review for Nintendo Wii U
